item.title: Comment on Africa facts of the day by Crusader
item.description:
Reply to Crusader:

As an Informed Citizen® and despite having no familial ties to Africa, I begin each day with a one hour briefing during breakfast of the last 24H of African conflict. My wife and kids aren’t the biggest fan, nor is my wife a fan of us spending 30% of our disposable income on our African conflict briefings, but I remind her it’s our responsibility to take the developments more seriously. I then arrive at work (US QSR manager) and spend the first 2 hours of my day distracted and anxious over any worrying Africa developments from the morning, and smugly sneer at my colleague Melinda who says hi to me and offers a donut with seemingly no worry in the world. I roll my eyes and mutter, “wow she’s making a good use of her life”

I jest, and obviously if I could wave a wand and fix issues across the world I would, and I certainly feel awful for anyone in Africa or elsewhere dealing with tragic conflict, but the point is that maybe the craziest thing we did over the last few decades was convince everyone they needed to be up to date on all current events and have beliefs on everything.

I know so many amazing people who should be happy and enjoying this brief life we get and instead are daily wrought with anxiety over things that don’t affect them. Of course, they are quite admirably empathetic and serious gems and I love them, but they have both zero ability nor actual willingness to solve some of the situations they let ruin or even just impair their day by learning about.

It’s obviously a nasty game theory problem where if no one cares then it’s a shame, so perhaps some people need to care and I’m complaining for no reason, but I just have a few family members and friends that I’ve seen had days ruined over seeing upsetting news in the morning and I just felt like it was a total shame.

item.title: Comment on Some Jimmy Carter observations from the 1970s by Charges
item.description:
I grew up in the late 70s and 80s and believed Carter was a fool. I was wrong. He was dealt a bad hand and made a strategic PR gaff by trying to reason with the electorate. He may have been a moralizer. But moralizing is just pitching an ideology and I’ll take an ideology of humbleness, compassion and peace over the one of raw power, cynical selfishness and divisiveness were about to live with for the next four years.
